bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, May 5, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg thanks Hench for his letter to Rankin concerning a medical portrait unveiling sponsored by Kellogg's company.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, May 5, 1942
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
May 5, 1942.
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
I can appreciate how upset you must be
because of your mother's illness. Kindly accept my
sympathy.

The fact that your work must have been
an increasing burden makes me all the more grateful for
the splendid letter which you wrote to Dr. Rankin. You
handled this in a masterly manner. Your letter together
with the press release which our Mr. Greene just sent
him for O.K. should smoke out the Colonel's intentions
entirely. I am sitting on the edge of my chair in antici-
pation of a wire which may say that he is heartily sick of
this McDowell business.

Frankly, doctor, in the language of the
street, I have been trying to settle the Colonel into this
proposition and he must know it by now, as his interest in
McDowell is mild indeed. On the other hand, he will have
to admit that I have been doing a nice job whether he likes
it or not.

I think Col. Rankin's answer to the question
we asked him would resemble that of Dr. Joseph Bloodgood on
some problem of medical history which I asked him many years
ago, “I am not interested in learning medical history. I am
trying to make it.”

All I can do is to hope for the best and thank
you again for your effort.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
GAK:L
